questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the lacunar ligament.

Lacunar (Gimbernat's) ligament - It is a thick triangular band of tissue formed from fibres of the medial end of the inguinal ligament and fascia lata.  It forms the medial wall of the femoral canal. The apex of the triangle is attached to the pubic tubercle.

Inguinal (Poupart’s) ligament - The thick external oblique aponeurosis stretched between ASIS (anterior superior iliac spine) and pubic tubercle. 

Pectineal (Astley-Cooper's) ligament - A strong fibrous band that extends laterally along the pectineal line from the pectineal attachment of the lacunar ligament.

Conjoint tendon - It is a condensation of tissue that runs through the lateral edge of the lower rectus sheath. It is formed from the common aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle and transverse abdominis muscle. The fibers turn inferiorly and insert into the crest of the pubis at the pectineal line immediately deep to the superficial inguinal ring.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

questions.solution:
The fibers of the iliopubic tract fan out with fascia iliaca laterally.

The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia lying immediately posterior to the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament. It extends from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) superolaterally and arches across the front of the femoral sheath.

Attachments:

  • Medially, its fibres insert by a broad attachment into the pubic tubercle and pectineal line, behind the conjoint tendon. 
  • Laterally, its fibres fan out within the fascia transversalis and fascia iliaca without bony attachment to the iliac spines. 

Clinical note: It is considered as an important landmark in laparoscopic hernia surgeries.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form the bony pelvis?
questions.solution:
The L5 lumbar vertebra does not form the bony pelvis.

The bony pelvis consists of four bones:

  • two hip bones
  • sacrum
  • coccyx

The articulations of these bones form four joints which are:

  • Two sacroiliac joints – Between the ilium of the hip bones, and the sacrum.
  • Sacrococcygeal symphysis – Between the sacrum and the coccyx.
  • Pubic symphysis – Between the pubis bodies of the two hip bones.

questions.text: A 33-year-old primigravida presented at term with non-engagement of the fetal head. She is suspected to have cephalopelvic disproportion at the level of inlet. Which of the following does not form the boundary of the involved structure?
questions.solution:
The structure involved in cephalopelvic disproportion at the level of inlet is the pelvic inlet. Ischial tuberosity does not form a boundary of the pelvic inlet.

Boundaries of the pelvic inlet:

  • Posterior - sacral promontory
  • Lateral - arcuate line on the inner surface of the ilium and the pectineal line on the superior ramus.
  • Anterior - pubic symphysis

 Boundaries of the pelvic outlet:

  • Posterior - tip of the coccyx
  • Lateral - ischial tuberosities and the inferior margin of the sacrotuberous ligament
  • Anterior - pubic arch

Clinical significance:

Cephalopelvic disproportion can occur when any of the inlet or outlet diameters are shortened by more than 0.5 cm, thus leading to the fetal head not getting engaged during labor. A primigravida presenting with a non-engaged head at term should raise suspicion of a contracted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion.

questions.text: A patient with sciatica was found to have inflammation of the muscle marked below. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the piriformis muscle. 

  • Origin:
    • The anterior surface of the sacrum
    • The posterior inferior iliac spine
    • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
    • Sacrotuberous ligament
  • Insertion - greater trochanter of the femur.
  • Action -  lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position

The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibres or below the muscle.

Clinical significance:

Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. This can occur due to inflammation of the piriformis muscle. The patient will present with pain along the distribution of the sciatic nerve which is also known as sciatica.

The following image shows relationship of sciatic nerve with the piriformis. 

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: Which of the following forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis?
questions.solution:
Obturator internus with its fascia forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis.

Muscles forming walls of the true pelvis:

  • Anterolateral wall - obturator internus and the fascia over its upper and inner (pelvic) surface.
  • Posterolateral wall - piriformis
  • Floor - levator ani and coccygeus

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with the following finding. Weakness of which of the following muscles could not have led to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and image is suggestive of uterine prolapse which occurs due to weakness of the levator ani muscle. Ischiococcygeus is not a part of the levator ani. It is a separate muscle that lies at the posterosuperior part of the pelvis and is not a part of the supports of the uetrus.

The levator ani forms a large portion of the pelvic floor. It is composed of three separate paired muscles:

  • Pubococcygeus - this starts from the posterior part of the pubis and runs lateral to the urethra and it' spinchter while passing through the pelvic floor.
  • Puborectalis - This muscle starts from the ischiopubic rami and runs medial to pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus to terminate posterior to the rectum at anorectal junction. 
  • Iliococcygeus - This muscle is placed posterior most as a triangular musculotendinous sheet where the apex is attached to the tip of the ischial spine and the base is attached to the lateral margin of coccyx and the fifth sacral segment.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the levator ani?

choices.text: Contraction leads to occlusion of the vaginal canal
Puborectalis and  pubococcygeus creates the anorectal angle
Arises from the condensation of the piriformis fascia

questions.solution:
The levator ani muscle arises from condensations of the obturator fascia which forms the tendinous arch of the levator ani.

The vaginal, urethral, and rectal lumen are occluded by the contraction of the levator ani and relaxation of the muscle is needed for defecation and urination.

The pubococcygeus and puborectalis parts of the levator ani help maintain the tone of the rectum as well as create the anorectal angle.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with erectile dysfunction, his internal pudendal artery was found to be stenosed. Which of the following​ vessels is this a branch of?

choices.text: Anterior division of internal iliac artery
Posterior division of internal iliac artery

questions.solution:
The anterior division of the internal iliac artery gives rise to the internal pudendal artery.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the anterior trunk of internal iliac artery:

  • Obturator artery
  • Superior vesical artery
  • Inferior vesical artery 
  • Inferior gluteal artery
  • Middle rectal artery
  • Vaginal artery (in females)
  • Uterine artery (in females)
  • Internal pudendal artery

Branches of the posterior trunk of internal iliac artery:

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: While examining a patient with a direct inguinal hernia, you note that the sac protrudes through the Hesselbach's triangle. Where does the structure forming its lateral boundary originate from?

choices.text: Anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery
Posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery

questions.solution:
The lateral boundary of Hesselbach's triangle is formed by the inferior epigastric artery. It originates from the external iliac artery.

The external iliac artery is the main artery of the lower limb. Its branches are:

  • Deep circumﬂex iliac 
  • Inferior epigastric
  • Small branches to psoas major and nearby lymph nodes
  • Femoral artery

Clinical significance:

Apart from being a landmark in hernia surgery, the inferior epigastric artery contributes to the corona mortis. This is an anastomosis between the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels. Iatrogenic injury in this region leads to torrential hemorrhage. 

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

questions.text: Which of the following is a tributary of the common iliac vein?
questions.solution:
The median sacral vein is a tributary of the common iliac vein.

Tributaries of common iliac vein:

  • Median sacral veins
  • Iliolumbar vein
  • Lateral sacral veins (occasionally)

Tributaries of internal iliac vein:

  • Superior and inferior gluteal veins
  • Internal pudendal vein
  • Obturator vein
  • Lateral sacral veins (usually)
  • Middle rectal vein
  • Vesical veins
  • Uterine and vaginal veins

Tributaries of external iliac vein:

  • Inferior epigastric vein
  • Deep circumﬂex iliac vein
  • Pubic vein

Clinical Note: Agenesis of the external iliac vein has been reported in association with Klippel–Trenaunay syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following structures given below is related to the structure highlighted (red) in the image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in red is the ischial spine and the pudendal nerve is related to it.

The pudendal nerve originates from the sacral plexus S2-S4. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor by passing around the ischial spine. The ischial spine is used as a landmark for pudendal nerve block.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form an anatomical boundary of the perineum?
questions.solution:
The sacrospinous ligament does not form an anatomical boundary of the perineum.

The perineum is a diamond-shaped region that overlies the pelvic outlet.

Boundaries of perineum:

  • Anteriorly: Pubic symphysis and its arcuate ligament.
  • Posteriorly: Coccyx
  • Anterolaterally: Ischiopubic rami and the ischial tuberosities.
  • Posterolaterally: Sacrotuberous ligaments

questions.text: A line between which of the following structures divides the perineum into anterior and posterior triangles?
questions.solution:
An imaginary line joining the ischial tuberosities (the inter-ischial line) divides the perineum into an anterior urogenital triangle and a posterior anal triangle.

The urogenital triangle faces downwards and forwards and has the following structures:

In males:

  • Scrotum
  • The root of the penis 

In females:

  • Mons pubis
  • Labia with the vestibule

The anogenital triangle faces downwards and backwards and has the following structures common to both males and females:

  • Anal canal with its sphincters
  • Ischioanal fossa with its contents

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the pelvis was diagnosed with urethral rupture. Imaging revealed extravasation of the urine into the superficial perineal pouch. The attachment of which ​of the following fascia prevents extravasation into the thigh and anal triangle?
questions.solution:
Colle's fascia prevents the extravasation of the urine from spreading into the thigh and anal triangle. 

Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the superficial fascia of the scrotum and becomes the Colles' fascia. In women, it continues into the labia majora and is continuous with the fascia of the perineum. Colle's fascia has the following attachments:

  • Posterior - perineal membrane. It prevents the extravasation of fluids such as blood, pus, or urine into the anal triangle. 
  • Lateral - ischiopubic rami and fascia lata along Holden's line. This line extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. It prevents the extravasation of fluids into the thigh. 

Option A: Camper's fascia is the superficial fatty layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option B: Scarpa's fascia is the deep membranous layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option C: Buck's fascia is the deep fascia of the penis 

Clinical significance:

When a urethral injury occurs, urine can extravasate into the superficial perineal pouch, penis, scrotum, labia majora and the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the superficial perineal pouch?
questions.solution:
Bulbourethral glands are not a content of the superficial perineal pouch. They are located in the deep perineal pouch. 

The superficial perineal pouch is a potential space between the perineal membrane above and the membranous layer of perineal fascia (Colle's fascia) below.

Contents of superficial perineal pouch:

Males Common to both Females
Root of the penis Urethra Body of the clitoris

Muscles: 

  • Two corpora cavernosa
  • Corpora spongiosa

Muscles:

  • Superficial transverse perinei
  • Ischiocavernosus
  • Bulbocavernosus
 Bulbs of vestibule

Perineal nerve branches:

  • Posterior scrotum
  • Bulb of penis
 Perineal nerve: muscular branches

Perineal nerve branches:

  • Labia
  • Bulbs of vestibule

Perineal artery branches:

  • Posterior scrotal artery
  • Branches of the penile artery

Perineal artery branches: 

  • Transverse perineal branch

Perineal artery branches:

  • Posterior labial artery
  • Branches of the clitoral artery
The duct of the bulbourethral gland   Greater vestibular gland and its ducts

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the deep perineal pouch?
questions.solution:
The root of the penis consists of two crura and one bulb. It is a content of the superficial perineal pouch.

The deep perineal pouch is used to describe the space enclosed between the endopelvic fascia and the perineal membrane and includes the following contents:

Males Common to both Females 
Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis 

Muscles:

  • Deep transverse perinei
  • Sphincter urethrae
 Nerves: Dorsal nerve of clitoris 

Arteries:

  • Penile artery
  • Origin  of the branches of the penile artery
 Arteries: 
  • Origin of the urethral artery

Arteries: 

  • Clitoral artery
  • Origin  of the branches of the artery of clitoris
Bulbourethral glands Urethra

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the formation of the perineal body?
questions.solution:
The internal anal sphincter is not involved in the formation of the perineal body.

The perineal body is a fibromuscular structure present in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangle. It attaches to various muscles in the pelvis:

  • Anterior - superficial and deep transverse perinei, bulbospongiosus
  • Posterior - external anal sphincter 
  • Superior - puborectalis, pubovaginalis and the rectovaginal septum 

It is continuous with the perineal membrane and the superficial perineal fascia. In males, it continues as the perineal raphe, and in females, it is attached to the posterior commissure and the introitus. 

The following image shows the perineal body and its muscular attachments.

Related Pearl: Perineal Body

The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

Category Muscles
Two unpaired
  • Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Fibres from External anal sphincter
Four Paired
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perenei
  • Deep transverse perenei
  • Levator ani

Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text: A surgeon is dissecting the ischioanal fossa in a patient with anal cancer. Which of the following statements is correct about its boundaries?

choices.text: Posterior boundary is the perineal membrane
Anterior boundary is the sacrotuberous ligament
Lateral boundary is the obturator internus
Medial boundary is the gluteus maximus

questions.solution:
The lateral boundaries of the ischioanal fossa are formed by obturator internus(with its fascia).

The ischioanal fossa is a wedge-shaped space on either side of the anal canal in the anorectal triangle. It has a pad of fat. The boundaries include:

  • Anterior: Posterior border of perineal membrane
  • Posterior: Gluteus maximus muscle, Sacrotuberous ligament
  • Lateral: Ischial tuberosity, Obturator internus
  • Medial: Sphincter ani externus, Pelvic diaphragm (levator ani).

Clinical significance:

Ischioanal fossa provides a relatively bloodless field during resection of anal cancers, therefore it is an important surgical plane.

questions.text: The fascia of which of the following muscles is involved in the formation of the Alcock's canal?
questions.solution:
The Alcock's (pudendal) canal is formed by the fascia of the obturator internus muscle.

It is formed by connective tissue binding the vessels and nerve to the medial surface of the fascia covering obturator internus.

Contents of the pudendal canal:

  • Internal pudendal artery and vein
  • Pudendal nerve

Clinical significance:

  • Infiltration of a local anesthetic around the trunk of the pudendal nerve at the level of the ischial spine results in analgesia of the lower vagina, posterior perineum, and vulva. 
  • Pudendal neuralgia can occur due to compression of pudendal nerve in the pudendal canal.
